segment.tokens: An English hunter tells a very affecting anecdote about two hares
about two hares were chased a pack of dogs
A hare they had pursued for some time
A hare was nearly
On the way he came across another hare , doubtless a personal friend of his
for there was not time for many ceremonies
a short conversation with the former -- for there was not time for many ceremonies -- took the place of the poor weary one
a short conversation with the former -- for there was not time for many ceremonies -- allowed himself to be chased the dogs
the other must soon have fallen a victim to the dogs
while the other was left to shift as best
The latter he could
The latter try to find a place of shelter
The hares in Liberia exhibit much foresight
In the month of August they cut great quantities of soft tender grass other herbs
other herbs they spread out to dry
This hay early in autumn they collect into heaps
This hay place either beneath the overhanging rocks around the trunks of trees , in conical heaps of various sizes , resembling the stacks in which men sometimes preserve their hay in winter
resembling the stacks
around the trunks of trees , in conical heaps of various sizes , resembling the stacks in which men sometimes preserve their hay in winter
The stacks the hares make
The stacks are much however not usually more than three feet high
In the winter these stacks are covered with snow
the animals make a path between them and their holes
They select the best of vegetables for their winter store
They crop them
when in the fullest vigor , and these they make into the best and greenest hay
Dr. Towson while in Gottingen succeeded getting a young hare so tame
that it would play about his sofa and bed
It would leap upon his knee
pat him with its fore feet
while he was reading
frequently it would jump up in his lap
it knock the book out of his hand so as to get a share of his attention
One Sunday evening five men were sitting on the bank of the river Mersey in England
singing sacred songs
where they were
The field had a forest on one side of it
As they were singing
a hare came of this forest
a hare ran toward the place where they were seated
where they were seated
When she came up very near the spot
she suddenly stopped
she stood still for a considerable time
she appearing to enjoy the sound of the music
She frequently turned her head as if listening with intense interest
When they stopped singing
she turned slowly toward the forest
She had nearly reached the forest
when the gentlemen commenced
singing again
The hare turned around
The hare ran back swiftly nearly to the spot where she stood before
where she stood before
The hare listened with the same apparent pleasure
until the music was finished
when she again retired toward the woods
she soon disappeared
Cowper was a great of pets
I confess
that I love him for this trait in his character
He has endeared himself to me indeed as much by the kindness he showed to the different animals which he had about him , and which he had taught to love him as by almost any other act of his

If the reader is as much in the poet

he will like to see a portrait of him
a portrait of him I introduce in this connection

He could not bear to hurt any thing
any thing lived

Cowper was to fits of great despondency , or depression of spirits
With him hypochondria was a of chronic disease
He would try
He knew the nature of his melancholy
He often tried to remedy indirectly
what could not be reached directly
He resorted to innocent amusements in order to lead the mind away from the contemplation of its own ills , real or imaginary
This was well
it was
it did not always succeed
The disease was too
seated in his system
The care he took of his pets
The care was no one of his favorite amusements
there were three of them at first

These hares had each very different characters
The poet described them in detail in one of his letters
Puss was the greatest
He was more tame affectionate than the rest

his master treated him with a great deal of kindness
his master gave him medicine
his master nursed him so well
that he recovered

Bess died young

He had a great fund of humor and drollery

When he died
and he lived to a good old age some nine years
I think
Cowper buried him with honor
Cowper wrote an epitaph for him
